Executive Summary



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Policies



Cloverhill Bakery is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner. A combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs is used to ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment. The comprehensive accidental release prevention program covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process. Unforeseeably, if a release is to occur, in order to provide the most effective means to control and mitigate the effects of an accidental release, Cloverhill Bakery has  their own highly trained emergency response team. The response team is in complete coordination with response teams from the Chicago Fire Department and Chicago Hazardous Materials team as well as directors at local hospitals.

Controlling accidents is and will continue to be a leading focus for the company and the individual employee.





Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



Cloverhill Bakery is a relatively new facility operated as a wholesale bakery located in Chicago, IL.  The facility operates one ammonia refrigeration system used to cool ingredient and freeze products.  Current anhydrous ammonia inventory consists of approximately 19,000 pounds.  The system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR1910.119) and is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA?s RM program.





Summary of Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios



For the worst case and alternative release scenarios, the EPA Model Risk Management Program and Plan for Ammonia Refrigeration and the EPA Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration (February 2008) were used for guidance.



WORST CASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons: 

?    Under normal operating conditions, the amm

onia inventory in the receivers is much lower

?    The worst cases weather conditions which were used for this scenario are not typical

?    Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of the receivers

?    The thermosyphon receiver and high pressure liquid lines are located in an enclosed area that could help contain such releases

?    The receivers are located in a low traffic area within the engine room which minimizes the possibility of a loss of containment due to vehicular impact

?    Ammonia is not corrosive in this service and the vessels are relatively new

?    The ammonia detector and ventilation fans, which are tied to emergency alarms, are located near the receivers in the engine room

?    Pressure safety valves limit operating pressure of the vessels

?    The facility has a preventative maintenance program in place to maintain the ongoing integrity of vessels

?    The facility has a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel

?    The facility emergency response procedures enable trained personnel to respond quickly to isolate potential releases



ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The alternative scenario was based on more credible assumptions and the following scenario was selected from a number of possible scenarios, based on their potential to reach off-site. As mentioned in the Ammonia Model RMP, this scenario would be representative of a gasket leak or pump seal leak.



The alternative release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons: 

?    Industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of the pumps at the facility

?    Ammonia is not corrosive in this service and the pump is relatively new

?    The facility has a preventative maintenance program in place to maintain the ongoing integrity of the pumps

?    The facility emergency response procedures enable trained personnel to respond quickly to isolate potential releases from any leaking equipment

?    Most lines are elevated,

limiting the potential for damage from traffic





Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

Cloverhill Bakery takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. Our management system addresses each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:



?    Employee Participation:  This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing the program. Employees have complete access to the program. Employees are also involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted. 

?    Process Safety Information:  Written information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the systems. The written information includes the ammonia MSDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration systems.

?    Process Hazard Analysis:  Formal studies using the What-If Technique have been conducted to look at the systems and identify potential hazards. 

?    Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration systems.

?    Training:  A training program has been developed which insures that employees who directly work with the ammonia system or safety of the system are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation or safe response to the system.

?    Contractors:  All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration systems.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.

?    Pre-Start up Safety Review:  A pre-start up safety review is completed for all new ammonia projects to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use.

?    Mech

anical Integrity:  This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration system is built and maintained using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.

?    Hot Work Permits:  These procedures ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding or burning.

?    Management of Change:  The procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration systems are properly reviewed.

?    Incident Investigation:  The procedures ensure that any incidents (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed and documented using an investigation team.

?    Compliance Audits:  There are procedures to conduct regular audits of the program to ensure that the program is in place and working properly.





Five-Year Accident History



No ammonia ?related incidents were identified for the facility in the previous five years, which resulted in significant on-site or offsite consequences.





Description of the Emergency Response Plan



An emergency response program has been implemented for Cloverhill Bakery to follow in the unlikely event a response is needed.  Procedures for responding to ammonia spills and other emergencies are described below:



?    Emergency Alerting and Response Provisions

?    Pre Emergency Planning and Coordination

?    Detailed Action Plans

?    Personnel Roles and Responsibilities

?    Preventive Maintenance

?    Safe Place of Refuge

?    Site and Security Control

?    Evacuation Routes and Procedures

?    Decontamination

?    Emergency Medical Treatment

?    Personal Protective Equipment

?    Critiquing after an Incident





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



To further strengthen the continuous safety efforts at Cloverhill, it has been recommended that updates to the training documentation be implemented to facilitate the training process and verification.
